person.title: Media Artist
person.byline1: As creative director of the Data Arts Team at Google, he develops data visualizations and web-based storytelling platforms, and uses crowdscourcing as a vehicle to collaborate with thousands of participants.
person.byline2: As creative director of the Data Arts Team at Google, Aaron Koblin develops innovative uses of data visualization, crowdsourcing, and web-based storytelling. He works with community generated data to reflect on cultural trends and the changing relationship between humans and the systems they create.

person.title: Artist, Programmer
person.byline1: Develops computer applications for visualization in biology and media arts. He currently works as a developer of Processing, a java-based open source programming language.
person.byline2: He is a research associate at the Harvard Sabeti Lab and designer at Fathom Information Design where he works with Ben Fry as one of the principal developers of the Processing toolkit.

person.title: Futurist, Design Critic
person.byline1: A science fiction writer and cyberspace theorist who is also still based there. His writing can be found on 'Beyond the Beyond', published by Wired magazine.
person.byline2: He blogs extensively on Beyond the Beyond, published by Wired Magazine and often features the work of hacker artists, programmers, inventors, critical engineers.

person.title: Data Visualizer
person.byline1: By encoding GPS information in images and objects, she engages with personal location data, and takes an innovative approach to mapping people's global journeys.
person.byline2: Rachel Binx's projects engage with personal location data, and take an innovative approach to mapping people's global journeys. By encoding GPS information in images and objects, she designs mementos that embody the latent associations between memory and place.

person.title: Artist, Educator
person.byline1: Writes software that explores the simple rules underlying complex systems. His short text instructions create images through the results of emergent processes. With Ben Fry, he created the Processing toolkit.
person.byline2: He studied in the Aesthetics and Computation Group at the MIT Media lab from 1999 to 2001. With Ben Fry, Reas initiated Processing in 2001. Processing is a java-based open source programming language and environment now used by thousands of artists and designers worldwide.

person.title: Artist, Programmer
person.byline1: As a creative engineer at the Ars Electronica Futurelab, her artworks experiment with technology in playful and curious ways and investigate topics such as artificial life, eye-tracking and optical illusions.
person.byline2: She has worked as a creative engineer at the Ars Electronica Futurelab, and a fellow at the Eyebeam Art and Technology Center.

person.title: Software Artist
person.byline1: He has a background in art, 3D graphics and interaction design. Creates physics-based visualizations using code. He strongly believes in working with others and sharing knowledge and skills.
person.byline2: In Amsterdam, he organizes a creative coding meetup in Amsterdam and contributes to Open Frameworks, an open source toolkit for creative coding.

person.title: Digital Media Artist
person.byline1: Prototypes future interfaces between humans, cameras and projectors. He is known for transforming a tree into an array of voxels, and performing other optical magic tricks with light and code.
person.byline2: He is known for transforming a tree into an array of voxels and for throwing augmented fireballs. He is a curator of the ScreenLab Residency in Manchester, co-founder of design company Kimchi and Chips based in Korea, and contributor to OpenFrameworks and VVVV, open source toolkits for creative coding.

person.title: Digital Media Artist
person.byline1: Prototypes future interfaces between humans, cameras and projectors and contributes to open source toolkits, VVVV and openFrameworks.
person.byline2: He is a curator of the ScreenLab Residency in Manchester, co-founder of design company Kimchi and Chips based in Korea, and contributor to OpenFrameworks and VVVV, open source toolkits for creative coding.

person.title: Computational Designer
person.byline1: Focuses on the social, collaborative, and artistic aspects of information visualization. She and collaborator, Martin Wattenberg, lead Google's 'Big Picture' data visualization group in Cambridge, MA.
person.byline2: A computational designer whose work focuses on the social, collaborative, and artistic aspects of information visualization. She is known for her pioneering work on depicting chat histories, email archives, and Wikipedia activityShe earned a PhD from the MIT Media Lab, focussing on the visualization of online communities. After founding Flowing Media, she and collaborator, Martin Wattenberg, now lead Google's 'Big Picture' data visualization group.

person.title: Media Artist, Educator
person.byline1: Explores the expressive use of computation, and focuses on the design of systems for performing simultaneous image and sound. He currently directs the STUDIO for Creative Inquiry, an arts research lab.
person.byline2: His work explores the expressive use of computation, and focuses on the design of systems for the performance of simultaneous image and sound. Levin applies creative twists to digital technologies that highlight our relationship with machines, combining equal measures of the whimsical, the provocative, and the sublime. He now directs the STUDIO for Creative Inquiry, an anti-disciplinary arts research lab at Carnegie Mellon University.

person.title: New Media Artist, Educator
person.byline1: Explores the expressive use of computation, and focuses on the design of systems for performing simultaneous image and sound. He currently directs an arts research lab at Carnegie Mellon University.
person.byline2: Explores the expressive use of computation, and focuses on the design of systems for performaning simultaneous image and sound. He currently directs the STUDIO for Creative Inquiry, an arts research lab at Carnegie Mellon University.Levin applies creative twists to digital technologies that highlight our relationship with machines, combining equal measures of the whimsical, the provocative, and the sublime.

person.title: Artist, Technologist
person.byline1: Creates illusions for humans and machines. As a researcher in the Playful Systems Group at the MIT Media Lab, he explores computer vision, machine learning, game design, and visual effects.
person.byline2: He is the author of the O'Reilly Book :Making Things See: 3D vision with Kinect.

person.title: Artist, Designer, Hacker
person.byline1: A Silicon Valley Unicorn, he is best known for developing generative computational aesthetics for Disney's TRON:Legacy. Independently he creates addictive software and viral videogames.
person.byline2: Josh Nimoy is a Silicon Valley Unicorn. His work ranges from traditional painting and print design to undefined technological experimentation. As a freelance commercial artist, Josh is best known for developing generative computational aesthetics for for Disney's TRON:Legacy. His own projects, developing addictive software and viral videogames, address the tension between the corporatization of creativity and individual expression. Josh is a member of OooShiny, an elite network of computer graphics virtuosos.

person.title: Experience Designer
person.byline1: Javier balances the relationship between technology and human interaction. As a designer at Culture Pilot, he creates emotionally resonant experiences that drive user engagement.
person.byline2: He works as a designer at Culture pilot, an interactive marketing company and is one of organizers of Visualized, a conference focussed on the communication of data.

person.title: Data Artist
person.byline1: Creates visualizations that tell stories and move people. Her research focuses on the implications of data in society, and communicating information through pictures.
person.byline2: Her research focuses on the implications of data in society, and communicating information through pictures. She is interested in creating visualizations that tell stories and move people. She is passionate about open data and open source tools. In her work with technology, she brings an education in applied math and information science, and a love of literature to her work. She is a founder of the School for Poetic Computation, with Zach Lieberman.

person.title: Data Artist
person.byline1: The former data artist in residence at The New York Times. His work focuses on adding narrative meaning to huge amounts of data.
person.byline2: The former data artist in residence at The New York Times. His work focuses on adding narrative meaning to huge amounts of data. In other words, he makes data more human.Through cutting edge data visualization techniques, Jer helps people and corporations take control of the information that surrounds them, using technology and data as a new way to tell stories.

person.title: Designer
person.byline1: Creates experiences that take people into the moment. His company Hellicar-Lewis develops interactive marketing experiences for major brands while advocating for an open source approach.
person.byline2: Joel creates experiences that take people into the moment. His company Hellicar Lewis creates interactive marketing experiences for major brands, while advocating for an Open Source approach throughout society. His projects bring together traditional media, interaction and digital networks to make feedback loops between people, technology and places.

person.title: Writer, Curator
person.byline1: Julia is editor at large for The Creators Project, and founded New York's ArtsTech meetup, a monthly event series exploring the intersection of art and technology.
person.byline2: Julia is passionate about technology's potential as an artistic medium as well as its ability to increase access to and engagement with the arts.

person.title: Critical Engineer, Artist
person.byline1: As an artist and hacker, he promotes privacy and transparency in the network domain. He co-wrote the Critical Engineering Manifesto, defining a more proactive stance on technology.
person.byline2: Oliver's artistic practice reflects his hacker and gaming background, playing around and messing with routers, capturing data from open wireless networks, visualizing protocols and otherwise manipulating networks for artistic purposes. Julian has given numerous workshops and master classes in software art, creative hacking, data forensics, computer networking, object-oriented programming for artists, virtual architecture, and artistic game-development worldwide.He is an advocate of Free and Open Source Software in education and is a supporter of, and contributor to, initiatives that promote privacy in the network domain.

person.title: Experimental Animator
person.byline1: Karolina works with animation, design, interactivity and computer games. Her work often engages public space and explores the way we engage with the worlds we create.
person.byline2: She has also studied and taught in the University of Washington's Digital Arts and Experimental Media PhD program. Her company, FlightPhase, creates large interactive installations in public spaces.

person.title: Computational Designer
person.byline1: From his origins in the East German 8-bit demo scene, Toxi has risen to the status of a creative software guru, as one of the most active contributors of open source libraries for 3D graphics.
person.byline2: The structure of software informs all aspects of Karsten's designs. When not creating, he travels the world consulting and teaching workshops on generative design approaches employing open source code as creative tool.

person.title: Media Theorist
person.byline1: As an entrepreneur he has successfully integrated digital media, game development, technology, and design. He co-founded Area/Code, where he designed real-world games using location-aware technologies.
person.byline2: Slavin argues that we're living in a world designed for–and increasingly controlled by–algorithms. His very popular TED talk, “How Algorithms Shape Our World,” has received over 2 million views. He now leads the Playful Systems group at the MIT Media Lab.

person.title: Writer, Curator
person.byline1: A freelance writer who covers digital media art, internet culture, and commerce for publications including The New Yorker, Pacific Standard, and The New Republic.
person.byline2: He has also curated exhibitions at Garis and Hahn gallery and Moving Image art fair in New York and London.

person.title: Artist
person.byline1: A regular collaborator on openFrameworks, his work with code ranges from hyper-formal glitch experiments to tactical interventions raising questions about the security of information and identity.
person.byline2: Kyle's work with code ranges from hyper-formal glitch experiments to tactical interventions raising questions about the security of information and identity. He is a regular collaborator on openFrameworks, having developed a number of extensions for image processing and computer vision. For the past few years, Kyle has applied these techniques to problems in 3D sensing, for interaction and visualization. He was recently Guest Researcher in residence at the Yamaguchi Center for Arts and Media, Japan, and is currently adjunct professor at ITP.

person.title: Artist, Programmer
person.byline1: As a social hacker, she explores the structures and systems of human interaction, identity, and self-representation, and the potential for technology to evolve these interactions.
person.byline2: She is fascinated by the slightly uncomfortable moments when patterns are shifted, expectations are broken, and participants become aware of the system.

person.title: Curator, Researcher
person.byline1: Explores how the Internet is shaping art and culture through a shift toward collaboration and open source philosophy. She is the curatorial fellow in residence at Eyebeam and co-director of 319 Scholes gallery.
person.byline2: Her experimental approach reflects a shift toward collaborative creativity, open source philosophy, and unlimited access to information. She founded 319 Scholes, a gallery dedicated to internet art, and hosts hackathons encouraging artist and technologists to collaborate.

person.title: Designer, Educator
person.byline1: Led one of the first research groups for computational art at the MIT Media Lab, and is a founding voice for simplicity in the digital age. His platform Design by Numbers inspired Processing.
person.byline2: His programming language, Design by Numbers, was the inspiration for Processing, an open source library invented by his students Casey Reas and Ben Fry during their time at the Media Lab. In 2008, Maeda became President of the Rhode Island School of Design (RISD).

person.title: Artist, Designer
person.byline1: Marcus uses programming and code libraries to expand the possibilities of traditional design. His company Field IO, with partner Vera Glahn, designs interactive installations, audiovisual performances, and videos.
person.byline2: His company Field IO, with partner Vera Glahn, applies the language of computational graphics to narrative experiences. They recently produced a non-linear film, Energy Flow: 10 animated story-lines exploring the theme of complexity.

person.title: Artist
person.byline1: Creates visual abstraction through generative software processes. His work focuses on the synthesis of form as the product of parametric behaviors. He lives between New York and Oslo.
person.byline2: Marius works with visual abstraction through generative software processes. His work focuses on the synthesis of form as the product of parametric behaviors. He is known for hard-edged geometrical forms and vivid colors, with outputs ranging from pure software works to public projections and physical objects produced with digital fabrication technology.

person.title: Data Artist
person.byline1: His work explores cultural and natural phenomena through the lens of data. He and collaborator Fernanda Viegas lead Google's 'Big Picture' data visualization group.
person.byline2: Martin focuses on visual explorations of culturally significant data. He has a particular interest is using visual tools to foster collaboration and discovery. He and collaborator, Fernanda Viegas, lead Google's 'Big Picture' data visualization group in Cambridge, MA. Exploring topics such as social networks and collaboration.

person.title: Engineer
person.byline1: Founder and Chief Science Officer of Nervous System, a generative design studio that uses computer programs to create unique and affordable art, jewelry, and housewares.
person.byline2: Drawing inspiration from natural phenomena, they write computer programs based on processes and patterns found in nature and use those programs to create unique and affordable art, jewelry, and housewares.

person.title: Designer
person.byline1: Founder and Creative Director of Nervous System, a generative design studio that uses computer programs to create unique and affordable art, jewelry, and housewares.
person.byline2: Drawing inspiration from natural phenomena, they write computer programs based on processes and patterns found in nature and use those programs to create unique and affordable art, jewelry, and housewares.

person.title: Design Curator
person.byline1: A senior curator in the Department of Architecture and Design at MoMA. As a longtime advocate for humanized technology and interdisciplinary thinking, her curation focuses on emerging approaches to design.
person.byline2: Her MOMA exhibitions, “Design and the Elastic Mind," and "Talk to Me", have featured the work of software artists, engineers and scientists. She recently established the museum's first collection of videogames.

person.title: Media artist
person.byline1: Interaction designer and VJ, one half of the Undef collective with Martin Fuchs. He has contributed numerous oFX addons to openFrameworks, a C++ toolkit for artists.
person.byline2: He has contributed numerous oFX addons to Open Frameworks, a c++ toolkit for artists.

person.title: Computer scientist, artist
person.byline1: By looking at code as a vehicle of thought, he develops new languages to explore the relationship between human imagination and machine instruction. Developed the first Arabic programming language.
person.byline2: Ramsey Nasser investigates programming languages as mediums of self expression. By looking at code as a vehicle of thought, he develops new languages to explore the relationship between human imagination and machine instruction.He wrote Alb, the first Arabic programming language, to provoke dialogue about the dominance of english in computer culture. His other work includes software and game design.

person.title: Blogger, Art Critic
person.byline1: Writes about the intersection between art, science and social issues on her blog we-make-money-not-art.com, highlighting the ways artists and hackers use science as a medium for critical discussion.
person.byline2: She also contributes to several European design and art magazines and lectures internationally about the way artists, hackers and designers use science as a medium for critical discussion.

person.title: Artist
person.byline1: Performs live drawings, projecting on surfaces, using drawing software to repeat patterns and make dynamic illustrations.
person.byline2: Martin uses live-painting and animation software to perform stream-of-consciousness, improvisatory drawings.She projects on surfaces, drawing to the beat of music, and uses drawing software to repeat patterns, zoom in and out on the canvas, and make the illustrations spin and "dance." Collaborating with Zach Lieberman, founder of Open Frameworks, introduced her to coding as an art form.

person.title: Programmer, Educator
person.byline1: Teaches programming to artists at NYU's Interactive Telecommunications Program. He is the author of the Nature of Code, a self published, open source book about simulating natural phenomena in software.
person.byline2: His work applies mathematical principles underlying physics to create digital worlds, which he develops through tutorials, examples, and libraries for Processing, an open source programming language and environment.

person.title: Artist, Researcher
person.byline1: Sofy examines the nature of objects and human action in relationship to their fragmented digital representations. Her work connects the artifacts of technological culture to universal human symbols and iconography.
person.byline2: Her practice coils together a variety of performance types, including musical performance with electronic instruments, spoken word, dance, techno-futuristic rituals, and site specific social experiments.

person.title: Artist, Designer
person.byline1: Develops playful interactive systems and software tools. He is the the co-founder of openFrameworks, an open source library for writing creative code in C++.
person.byline2: His company Design IO, with partner Emily Gobeille, creates immersive environments that engage full-body interaction.

person.title: Designer, Project Manager
person.byline1: Along with partner Marcus Wendt at Field IO, she uses her curatorial and filmmaking background to create interactive installations, audiovisual performances, and videos.
person.byline2: Field recently produced a non-linear film, Energy Flow, consisting of 10 animated story lines exploring themes of complexity, chaos and interconnectivity.

person.title: Artist, Educator
person.byline1: Explores new modes of expression and play. Develops openFrameworks, a C++ library for creative coding, and co-founded the School for Poetic Computation in Brooklyn, NY.
person.byline2: He co-founded and develops open Frameworks, a C++ library for creative coding. He recently founded The School for Poetic Computation in Brooklyn, to bridge the gap between computer programming, engineering, design and art.

person.title: Artist
person.byline1: Brings a background in experimental psychology to designing spaces where creativity and play offer tranformative experiences.

person.title: Artist, Programmer
person.byline1: A creative coder who develops interactive art, games and apps. As an artist-in-residence at Yamaguchi Center for Arts and Media (YCAM), he has collaborated with artist Daito Manabe.
person.byline2: Higasan has contributed numerous add-ons to open Frameworks, a C++ library for artists.

person.title: Software artist
person.byline1: An anonymous software artist active in early net art sites re-move.org, turux.at, and processing.org. She develops generative visual systems, apps, installations, and live audioreactive performances.

person.title: Sound Artist, Engineer
person.byline1: Works with sound, code, light, and electronics to create immersive environments that alter the viewer's sense of time and space. He moonlights as a freelance engineer developing creative mobile apps.
